Merge pull request #1835 from glasserc/http-api-string

Http api string
Add test covering read_env use of native_value
Add test covering correct location of native_value
Update CHANGELOG

Properly encode http_api_version

Settings are decoded from strings. Since we want to encode the string
"1.20", the entry in the settings dictionary should be more like
"\"1.20\"". Use JSON serialization to do this automatically.

All of these should be strings, but for non-strings we fall back to
just using their literal values.

Only native_value things from the environment

The `value` should be understood to be a Python value already. If it
wasn't a Python value, it should be deserialized towards the "edges",
not here.

Because we call `from_env` multiple times, this prevents us from
multiply-deserializing values.

Settings loaded from the settings files are still strings, so
deserialize them in `load_default_settings`.
Failing test for HTTP_API_VERSION

@glasserc review

Fix example in docs
Raise error if accounts is misconfigured (fixes #1734)

Another test about event merging

This accidentally highlit an issue I didn't realize I had about event
merging.
Add test for event cascading

Extract EventCollector

Because we handle resource events twice -- once to emit
ResourceChanged and ResourceRead events, and then a second time to
emit AfterResourceChanged and ResourceRead events, we have to keep
track of the drained events. Because we might need to "merge" events
here as well as in the original notify_resource_event function,
extract the logic for managing collections of events into a separate
class, EventCollector. Draining the EventCollector is done with an
iterator that is built around the builtin dict.popitem() method.

This restores the `get_resource_events` API from before this branch
started, but it is now a generator rather than a simple accessor.

changelog
comment cleanup and fix test
replace doom method with abort method

Sort before you paginate

Leaving the sorting criteria at the end of the query causes Postgres
to fetch all the records first, count them, and then sort them (which
is probably O(n log n)) so that it can select the right page.

Moving the sorting criteria closest to the data means that Postgres
will try to use an index (if possible/available) to generate records
in the right order. This eliminates the cost of doing a sort. However,
it more or less enforces that we will be scanning records via the
index, even if scanning the whole table would be faster and generate
comparatively few records (i.e. few enough that sorting would be
fast).

Simplify Postgres get_all query

This DISTINCT id leads to difficulties when, as with wildcard
parent_ids, multiple records have the same ID. This manifests as
re-selecting the same record in multiple "pages" because its id
matched once.

This DISTINCT also costs us performance because we have to stick every
record in a hash in order to deduplicate it, and then do an expensive
join afterwards to get the record back. None of this is really
necessary, so just delete it.

Don't use ID as a unique key for any given query

Because parent_id with wildcards can match different objects that have
the same ID, this old use of records indexed by IDs to get the union
of a bunch of records no longer works. Instead, rely on the fact that
the same record, matched multiple times, is the same object in
memory, and use its memory location as its unique ID. This is kind of
a hack, but I couldn't think of a better solution.

Although this is one obvious place where we rely on every object in a
given "result set" having a unique ID, there may be others hidden
elsewhere.

Refs: #1616

Introduce failing test for parent_id and pagination

this test, but in different ways.

Guess schema_version 20 if metadata seems to have been flushed

Fixes #1460.

Flushing should not wipe metadata

Flushing should wipe data, but not damage the schema. However, the
version of the schema is wiped, which makes it hard to figure out what
schema we have. There's some hacky code in the storage schema that
assumes that if the schema version is missing, we must be "up to
date", but honestly we shouldn't ever monkey around with the metadata
table in this way. This becomes increasingly important because I don't
want to duplicate this hack in the permission backend migration code.

Fix a couple tests to stop touching the metadata table and instead use
the records table, which is flushed predictably.

Merge pull request #1454 from glasserc/add-collation-to-timestamps

Add collations to the timestamps table
Update CHANGELOG

Add collations to the timestamps table

The trigger bump_timestamp does a query against the timestamps table
using the parent_id and collection_id from the records table (which
are now collation C). If the timestamps columns are not of collation
C, the primary key indices could potentially include different
sequences of letters that should be considered equal, or equal
sequences of bytes which are considered different by the collation, so
Postgres does not use the index. This makes all queries against the
timestamps table perform a table scan, which performs very
badly. Because every request of a default_bucket does at least one
create(), this makes every single HTTP request very expensive.

If we update the collation of the columns in the timestamp table to
match the records table, the queries should return to their previous speed.

Update changelog

Update id columns of records table to be collation C

This is correct because these IDs are not meant to be human language
and should not have human language collation enforced (for example,
sort order should not follow en_US rules). It also allows us to use
built-in indexes when doing prefix matching on parent_id in
delete_all.

Add changelog entry

Fix TOCTOU bug in postgresql create

Doing a get() and then an insert() later risks another transaction
inserting something between the get and the insert. The correct way to
handle this is to just go ahead and try the insert but detect
conflicts. In order to do this, we do a complicated
SELECT-or-INSERT-or-UPDATE based on some examples from
StackOverflow. We upsert to replace any tombstones, but we combine
that with a select to detect any existing non-tombstone records.

Writing a test for this is tricky because it requires two
transactions, one which happens in the middle of the get() method, so
let's not even try.

Add a test for paginating with MISSING

Fix test

Pagination needs to handle missing fields correctly, because we handle
NULLs (i.e. MISSINGs) as comparing greater than everything
else. Otherwise, we generate a token for a MISSING and resume the next
page on JSON ``null``s, which skips from the top of the sort to the
bottom.

Because this commit promotes MISSING from the memory backend, it works
correctly there. However, the Postgres backend probably needs to be
updated.

Merge branch 'master' into 1187-upgrade-pyramid-tm

Turn ResourceChanged from beforeCommit into a tween

beforeCommit hooks are invoked once you've already decided to commit
the transaction. Raising an exception from this point isn't really
well supported. Instead, let's use a tween to send the events once the
request handler is over. We put it under the EXCVIEW so that
exceptions are rendered using exception views. pyramid_tm handles this
case explicitly ("squashed exceptions"), so everything works fine.

We no longer need is_numeric
Introduce `has` operator

Tests for new "has" operator

This will be necessary to handle some test breakages that comes from
our handling of NULLs.

Straighten out comparison order for the memory backend

This is explicitly the same as the Postgres backend, at least as a
first approximation. The full complete comparison order isn't
implemented, and I expect probably won't ever be implemented as I
think the only logical way to handle different storage backends is to
allow them to enforce their own sort order. However, a couple of tests
rely on this sort order for all sort backends, so enforce it.

Straighten out the comparison order for Postgres

(Or, you could say we "sorted out" the comparison order...)

This isn't necessarily the best possible sort order, but it's the one
that Postgres supports natively, so let's capitalize on that. We may
have to allow different storage backends to define their own sort
order, but we have a couple tests that rely on sort
order (test_get_all_can_deal_with_none_values and
test_get_all_can_filter_with_numeric_values) so let's just go with
this one.
Add test to enforce consistent ordering

Needless strip()

json.dumps() will never return a value like '"....."' unless the input
value was a string, which was just ruled out by the if statement above.

Add a bunch of tests for filtering using JSON-based objects

The storage tests fail hard in Postgres because everything is being
cast to a string. Filters mostly work in memory except for None
because of special handling that imitates how Postgres works. The view
test passes because it works against memory, it's just a sanity check.

add changelog entries

Update and fix tests

The last version of the tests had a small imprecision. When we created
the stored record on setUp using the model, we produced a record
with an incremented `last_modified` that was ahead of the server
timestamp. This tries to fix this by creating the record using the
model and than update it using the resource to make the timestamps
match.

This also tries to simplify a bit the tests setting record_id on
the setup.

Use strong comparisons with preconditions

Implement strong comparisons (matching on Equal and Not Equal) Etags
for preconditions `If-Match` and If-None-Match` as RFC 2616.
@leplatrem comments

Merge pull request #1100 from Kinto/fix-forbidden-status

Fix status of 403 Forbidden in docs
minor (sleepy) fixes
add an fix tests

Propose and clarify the If-Match behavior

This changes the `If-Match` behavior in order to fix any inaccuracies
in the previous one. It also tries to be "closer" to the RFC spec.

Proposed changes:
- If-Match raise on with non-existing records (including Tombstones)
- If-Match:* succeeds if the record exist.
- If-Match and If-None-Match a assume a colection is a resource
  that always exists, so If-None-Match:* on a collection will fail
  while If-Match:* will succeed.

Return JSON on __flush__ endpoint (fixes #1098)

Make `__flush__` return an empty JSON object instead of an HTML
page to make it consistent with the rest of the API.

Use cornice swagger to generate the OpenAPI documentation (#1078)

* Implement basic cornice swagger generation

Use cornice swagger to generate the /__api__ view without any
additional information about services.

* Add default tags and operation Ids

These features are used in several swagger related services and
the defaults match all the kinto resource names described on the
handwritten spec. They my be updgraded to support other plugin
resource names.

* Use a colander schema to deserialize errors

Use a colander error schema on `kinto.core.errors` so we can use
it for documentation and simplify the current error response
generation.

* Add resource response schemas

These changes add cornice swagger like schemas to document Kinto
resource responses.

Basically, the responses are wrapped into a handling class that
join response schemas for each method/endpoint type and bind
the record schema for each one of them. This class always
return a dict mapping the status code and the response as expected
by cornice swagger.

* Add utility endpoints simplified response schemas

* update requirements

* Provide OpenAPI documentation with OPTIONS

* remove handwritten spec

* @glasserc comment

* Add security extensions

These changes allow adding security extensions via a class method
``expose_authentication_method`` which should be called on the
module includeme.

* Drop Options support for another PR

* Fix non-swagger related tests

* Fix swagger tests

These changes fix some details and update the swagger tests to
match the new implementation. Below are some change specific
considerations:

- Definition tests were removed because now we don't have explicit
definitions and we trust cornice_swagger to create valid schemas.
- History tags and ids are set manually because they don't match
the default generator pattern and changing this would involve
language tricks (pluralize words).
- Admin was removed from the API listing because it's not part of
the API (is an user interface).
- Our previous id validation was wrong. I removed the basic string
validation and will leave proper id validation on swagger for a
next PR.

* add generator tests

* add documentation

* python3

* fix docs

* Add resource response tests

* document missing swagger view

search-and-replace in cliquet_docs

The name of the thing formerly known as Cliquet is now Kinto-Core. This
isn't super ideal and another cleanup pass will be necessary on this
documentation to make sure it makes sense.

was `cliquet` is now under `kinto`.
get rid of public settings prefixes
get rid of cliquet_protocol_version

get rid of initialize_cliquet

We're going to have to release a major version anyhow. May as well get
rid of this deprecated code.

get rid of kinto/core/scripts/cliquet

There's really only one thing here that's valuable, and that's the
actual migrate command. Leave that around in case someone else wants
it. The fact that kinto, the major cliquet application to date, doesn't
use anything else here, suggests we don't need it. Perhaps we were
keeping it around for the sake of having an example for other
authors. In that case, the kinto script is probably sufficient.
rename cliquet_ imports to core_
kinto.core.tests -> kinto.tests.core in code

move tests from kinto/core to kinto/tests/core

Anything in kinto/ that isn't in kinto/tests/ has to have 100%
coverage. That doesn't seem valuable to me.

At the same time, we want to maintain a distinction between the "core"
part of the library which people might build servers out of, and the
non-core thing that people will just run.

kinto/tests/core seems like a good compromise.

make_testapp to get around this.

kinto init changes
kinto init command

Load plugins after setting up authn/authz

While developing kinto-attachment, we realized that if plugins were included
before setting-up authn/authz, their views could not be protected by permissions.

For example, when a plugin defines a plugin like this in a view:

```python

    upload = Service(name="upload",
                     path="/upload",
                     description="",
                     factory=RouteFactory)
    @upload.get(permission="upload")
    def upload_get(request):
        return {"ok": True}

```

The factory is taken into account, but the authorization policy was never
called!

With this change, the plugins are included after ``cliquet.initialization.setup_authentication()``. Thus after ``config.include("pyramid_multiauth")`` thus after setting
up the authorization policy from setting ``multiauth.authorization_policy``.

The side-effet of this is that plugins cannot set default settings regarding auth.
It was the case of *cliquet-fxa* which defines an implicit setting ``multiauth.policy.fxa.use`` that allowed to just to specify ``fxa`` in the ``multiauth.policies`` setting.

The setting ``multiauth.policy.fxa.use`` must now be defined explicitly.

Merge pull request #231 from mozilla-services/186-215-add-sqlachemy-pooling

Use SQLAlchemy for pools and connections instead of raw psycopg2 (fixes #186, #215, #171)
Disable fsync=off and use static pool on travis

Use SQLAlchemy instead of raw pyscopg2

SQLA presents several advantages:

* It has advanced pooling features (like connection refresh/recycle)
* It will allow per-request transactions, using pyramid-tm
* It will allow cliquet applications to implement custom storage backend using SQLAlchemy tools

However, it **does not** introduce:

* SQL abstraction or ORM
* Heterogenous backends like SQLite or whatever

Merge pull request #195 from Kinto/192-default-bucket-optimizations

First set of optimizations (fixes #192)

Add request bound data, shared with subrequests.

This allows to store any arbitrary data in a ``dict`` on the current request,
instead of setting custom attributes and testing their existance.

It is shared with subrequests during batch.

In the short term, this will allow us to reduce storage hits in batch
subrequests on the default bucket in Kinto.

In the long term, this will allow us to share storage connections accross
batch subrequests.

Handle CORS settings.

Create a subclass of the default cornice "Service" class, rather than
cluttering the default ones with defaults that are sensible only for cliquet.

I though it would be possible to add the CORS information at registration time
(when the venusian callback is called again in the "register_resource"
function, but it would have worked only for resources.
Add permissions to the view arguments.

Handle permissions.

Of course, this is a really simple way to handle the permissions. Any method
listed in the "readonly_method" will have the "readonly" permission required,
and all the other ones will require the "readwrite" permission.

One benenfit of defining this in the ViewSet class is that implementers can
shortcut any complexity here if they need, by always returning the same fixed
string.

Pass viewset's service arguments when registering.

Otherwise the service cannot know which behaviour it should have on error, for
instance.

Delegate name finding to the viewset.

ViewSets are responsible for giving any information to the registering
mechanism. Previously, the name was directly asked to the resource "using
resource.name", having the disadvantage to not allow any customization by the
user of the library.

Now this is possible with ViewSets.
Add docstrings about registering mechanisms and viewset
Fix unittests for resource viewset / register
Use register as a decorator and fix venusian integration

Ask the viewset where the views are located in a resource.

Rather than having magic locations defined in the register function, it seems
better to have this defined in the viewset, so different viewsets can work in
different ways.

Remove unicode content from CONTRIBUTORS file.

In setup.py it should be read like this in python3:

    f = open('CONTRIBUTORS.txt', encoding='utf-8')

and in python 2:

...so instead of introducing compat code in setup, just
remove utf8 from CONTRIBUTORS file.

This reverts commit 507f720c919b4af4ef1d78f5bd928660c8b2ca96.
Use bidirectionnal conversion for epoch/timestamp

Get rid of redundant indices (ref #138)

Indices are not restricted to those used in queries. Indexing an individual column
if it is not used in queries is a waste.

This PR removes redundants indices and make sure they are used in queries.

Plus, it improves creation significantly (~35%):

*before*

    testdb=# INSERT INTO records(id, user_id, resource_name, data) SELECT uuid_generate_v4(), * FROM generate_records(100000, 1, 10);
    INSERT 0 1000000
    Time: 114463,644 ms

*after*

    INSERT INTO records(id, user_id, resource_name, data) SELECT uuid_generate_v4(), * FROM generate_records(100000, 1, 10);
    INSERT 0 1000000
    Time: 73150,822 ms

Fix migration behaviour when metadata table was flushed.

We now consider the schema as the last version if metadata is empty.
